welcome to hot thai kitchen so today i'm going to 
make sweet and sour crispy noodles which entire

called mee grob so me are thin rice vermicelli 
which is these and grub as the way it sounds means

crispy so these are sort of like savory asian 
rice crispy squares they're super popular snacks

especially amongst tourists in thailand and they 
are not hard to make however if you don't know

what you're doing there could be a lot of problems 
with it either noodles don't puff up properly or

they're like they get soggy they don't stay crispy 
or they're too sweet so today i'm gonna share with

you all the secrets that you need to know and 
if you follow them i guarantee you you will have

crispy delicious noodles that stay crispy for 
weeks you can package them sell them as a side

hustle that is how good they're going to be all 
right let's get started so the me that we are

using are these thin rice vermicelli which you can 
get at just about any asian grocery store what you

want to do is separate them into sort of smaller 
bundles because when we fry these they will puff

up a lot so you only want to fry a small bundle 
at a time and this is a little long so i just cut

and that's it so this is about a good 
amount to fry in like a pot this size

secret number one you need to weigh 
your ingredients so this is not

a recipe where you can just willingly eyeball 
things because the ratio between the noodles

and the sauce is everything too little and it's 
bland too much and it's too sweet and sticky so

you can tinker with it afterwards but i 
would follow the recipe to a tea the first

time secret number two for fluffy light not 
oily noodles your oil has to be screaming hot

at least 430 degrees fahrenheit between 430 
and 450 works actually i'm going to show you

what the noodles look like when the oil is not hot 
enough so even if you don't have a thermometer you

can gauge by the behavior of the noodles my oil is 
at 350 now this is a temperature at which you fry

most things it's taking its time it's not puffing 
right away which is not what we want so i'm going

to remove my sacrifice noodles and it's actually 
browning without puffing at all so we're now at

390 400. it's getting there but it's not if it 
doesn't make you jump it's not hot enough 420

oh so close so close you can 
see it's trying so hard 4 30
it's pretty it's okay but it's i think 450

is kind of where you need to go but you can 
see the volume is starting to increase now 450

like you can see how much more volume that has 
right so here they all are all the different

noodles for at a different temperature and the 
interesting part is the lower the temperature the

browner the noodles i'm not 
really sure why that happened

but it does and as you get higher and higher 
you get this fluffy white light and the

volume increases so much more and that's 
what you want and when you break it off

it's just super light whereas if you take 
one fried at lower temperature it's harder

like you can almost hear it right it's not 
it's not fluffy even this one is is not fluffy

430 is okay this was on his fried at 4 30 it's not 
as white but fluffiness wise it's okay but really

the best is 450. all right let's fry the rest of

room best you can i've turned the fan on and then 
please enjoy the asmr effect of frying noodles
hmm

wow i'm just checking my final oil temperature and 
it seems i went up to 475 which is still good you

can see the noodles were really puffing up at 
the end but the oil is starting to smoke now so

for quality of the oil's sake keep it around 450 
is probably your best bet okay now that all that

excitement is over let's move on to the part 
where it's less likely to result in a disaster

i'm going to make the sauce is a sweet and sour 
sauce that has a lot of the same ingredients as

pad thai actually so i like to think of these 
as crispy pad thai so gonna start out with some

oil and some shallots and i'm gonna cook the 
shallots until they're nice soft and caramelized

so keep the heat relatively low for this and 
choice of cookware i want to use something that's

big because we want the sauce to evaporate and so 
you want that to happen sooner rather than later

and also i'm using a non-reactive wok so no carbon 
steel no cast iron because the sauce is acidic

and so you that is going to eat away at your metal 
starting to smell good the smell of fried shallots

just going to put these a little bit further 
so that they're a little bit more caramelized

but not burnt more caramelized more caramelized 
living on the edge here okay that's all i have the

patience for it's good enough next an egg it might 
be a surprising choice to add an egg oh no shell

but the eggs are kind of just like gonna 
get candied in the sweet sauce not even be

visible but they do add almost substance some 
protein and of course a little bit of flavor as

well you don't have to add it i've seen lots of 
recipes that don't add the egg in the sauce but

i do think they add a little something something 
and now super easy we're going to add all of the

seasoning which includes palm sugar lots and lots 
of palm sugar because this is a sweet and sour so

that's the sweet the sour is tamarind you want 
to know how to make tamarind paste yourself i

do have a video for that i will link to fish sauce 
for salty now i'm going to add some thai sriracha

for a little bit of spiciness and also that 
iconic orange color if you are making this for

kids and you don't want it spicy at all you can 
add a little bit uh you can add ketchup instead

or do half and half i'm actually going to do fish 
sauce and salt just to make it a little bit less

fishy for some people who might want something 
a little more neutral some lime juice and also

i'm going to add some lime zest now traditionally 
meat crop uses a type of citrus called somsa

which i've never even seen they're really hard 
to find even in thailand i don't know what it

smells like but i like the the smell of lime zest 
just fine you can try different citrus you can

do a combination of lime and lemon you can do a 
combination of lime and orange people say that it

smells kind of like half lime half orange 
but i think wine works just fine for me

okay secret number three the last secret you're 
going to cook this sauce down until it's very

thick but don't eyeball the thickness what you 
want to do is measure the temperature of the sauce

and it should reach 240 degrees fahrenheit which 
is a softball stage in the way of candy making and

that's the temperature it needs to reach in order 
for it to not turn the noodles soggy when you put

the noodles in you can imagine all of the liquid 
noodles go in now they're just gonna turn soft and

soupy right but if you cook the sugar down so much 
it becomes really hard and then it's just too hard

and then it becomes a hard candy you don't want 
that you still want it to be kind of soft but no

absolutely no moisture no water left to soften the 
noodles okay that's the main secret of this recipe

so keep cooking keep stirring because it will 
start to burn to the bottom if you stop stirring

we are super close this is what it should look 
kind of like let's take temperature so never

trust your eyes we're at 225 so a little bit more 
to go oh and if you see any big chunks of eggs

just break them up because you don't really want 
big chunks because that'll be really overpowering

when you eat it 2 35 to 36 37 39 40 41 okay 
we are good just for now i'm going to turn off

the heat so that it doesn't burn on the bottom 
while i'm not looking and then i'm going to add

all of these noodles in here yes does not look 
like it's gonna fit but we will crush it down

and now with two spatulas i'm gonna just toss

back on just a very very low just because when 
it's hot the sauce is softer and it's easier to

get everything mixed and you want to be really 
vigilant with any clumps of sauce because that

will be overwhelming when you eat it and i swear

this is good here's the cool part once you get

super easy the hard work is already done but

as well but today let's make some snacks 
i'm just gonna pack these halfway up because

i really love adding cashews or some sort of nuts 
to it it really adds some nuttiness that contrast

you know with the all carbs situation that we've 
got going so i got cashews which i painstakingly

split in half you can also just chop them but

just for color i'm just gonna do pumpkin seeds

they all fall to the bottom when i do that which 
i found out the hard way and then i have to rescue

then the rest of this goes on top and then we'll

put more nuts on top see that just brings them

fill the gaps and you want to do this 
while they're still warm so the sugar

hasn't quite solidified and they'll be much

and cut them into cubes okay so this has

just to be sure and you can cut it in the pan if

you can hear the crispiness yay look

so i have more pretty ones for photos

you can hear the crispy right and light fluffy 
not sticky perfect balance of sweet salty and sour

these are better once you've let them sit for a 
while they're okay to eat right now but if you

let them sit maybe have like overnight half a 
day at least the flavor will sort of start to

penetrate into the noodles and it'll be more even 
out a little bit you know how like lasagna tastes

better the next day it's kind of the same idea 
pro tip when you put it in a container or whatever

there are some common garnishes including fried 
macro lime leaves and fried chilies if you want

you can eat these these are crispy fries just 
in the same oil that you fried the noodles but

lower at like 325 350. but if you pack it in the 
container with the chilies and the lime leaves the

smell will actually slowly infuse into the noodles 
and after a few days you can taste the lime leaves

and even the smell of the chili in the noodles so
